CAS Key Laboratory of Low-carbon Conversion Science & Engineering Shanghai Advanced Research Institute Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 201210 PR China Graphical abstract The effects of preparation methods of CoMn-based catalysts on the precursor phase of Co species, the morphology of Co2C nanostructures as well as the catalytic performance for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins were investigated. The effects of preparation methods for CoMn-based catalysts on the precursor phase of Co species, the morphology of Co2C nanostructures as well as the catalytic performance for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins were investigated. Five catalysts prepared by precipitation and impregnation methods were compared in detail. CoMn spinel oxide was found in the calcined catalysts prepared by co-precipitation or sequential precipitation starting from the Co salt. However, Co3O4 and MnO2 were the major phases for the calcined catalysts prepared by sequential precipitation starting from the Mn salt or impregnation methods. During the syngas conversion process, Co2C nanoprisms with exposed facets of (101) and (020) were generated from CoMn spinel phase, and exhibited high CO conversion, low methane selectivity and high olefins selectivity. In contrast, Co2C nanospheres carburized from metallic Co or CoO were observed for the other samples with poorer FTO catalytic performance. Keywords Syngas conversion Fischer-Tropsch to olefins Preparation methods Cobalt carbide CoMn 1 Introduction Conversion of syngas, a mixture of H2 and CO that derived from coal, nature gas or biomass, is a promising alternative non-petroleum process to produce fuels [1,2] and valued-added chemicals such as olefins [3,4], oxygenates [5,6] and aromatics [7,8]. As lower olefins (referring to ethylene, propylene and butylene) are widely applied in the manufacture of plastics, polymers and other products in the chemical industry, the direct production of lower olefins from syngas attracts significant interest among academic and industrial communities [9]. Recent researches show that the oxide-zeolite (OX-ZEO) bifunctional route [10,11] and Fischer-Tropsch to olefins (FTO) [12,13] allow for direct production of lower olefins from syngas with high selectivity. The bifunctional catalysts in the OX-ZEO route usually combine an oxide component for CO activation and a zeolite component for CC coupling [14]. Jiao et al. [10] developed a bifunctional ZnCrOx/SAPO-34 catalyst with olefins selectivity of 80 % at CO conversion of 17 %. They suggested that the partially reduced oxides could activate CO and H2 to form ketene (CH2CO) as intermediates, which further diffused into the acidic zeolite pores to perform CC coupling that producing lower olefins [10]. Meanwhile, Cheng et al. [11] designed a bifunctional catalyst consisting of Zr-Zn binary oxides and SAPO-34, which exhibited around 70 % selectivity for C2-C4 olefins at about 10 % CO conversion. It was demonstrated that the Zr-Zn binary oxides were responsible for the activation of CO to form methanol or methoxide as surface intermediates, and SAPO-34 was responsible for the selective CC coupling [11]. Other bifunctional catalytic systems such as MnOx/SAPO-34, InZrOx/SAPO-34, ZnCrOx/AlPO-18 [15–17] were also investigated for CO hydrogenation to lower olefins. In the case of the FTO route, iron-based catalysts are widely investigated. Torres Galvis et al. [12] found that Na- and S-promoted iron-based catalysts showed excellent performance for lower olefins production. They revealed that the appropriate amount Na and S promoters could suppress the formation of methane and deactivate sites for the secondary hydrogenation of olefins [18]. Zhai et al. [19] reported a Zn- and Na- modulated iron carbide catalysts, and the selectivity of olefins was up to 79 % at 340 °C, where Zn and Na served as structural and electronic promoters, respectively. Although the formation of Co2C was considered to mainly cause deactivation in the Co-based Fischer-Tropsch reaction, Zhong et al. [13] proposed that Co2C nanoprisms with specifically exposed facets of (101) and (020) derived from CoMn composite oxides could directly convert syngas to lower olefins with surprisingly high selectivity and very low methane formation under mild reaction conditions (∼ 250 °C). It was demonstrated that the facet effect of Co2C nanostructure played a vital role in the product distribution. As CO hydrogenation is a structure-sensitive reaction, the catalyst structure including crystalline phase, particle size and exposed facets will greatly influence the catalytic performance [20]. To precisely control the surface structure of the active phase, many factors including additives [18,21,22], supports [12,23], reduction process [24], reaction conditions [25] and preparation methods [26–28] should be considered. We previously explored the effect of Na and Mn promoters on the structure-performance relationship of Co2C, and found that Na acted as an electronic donor to promote the formation of Co2C phase [22], while Mn not only acted as a structural promoter but also affected the final morphology of Co2C [21]. For support effect, it was reported that inert supports weakly interacting with active metals favored the formation of Co2C nanoprisms by influencing the formation of CoxMn1-xO intermediate [23]. The important role of CoxMn1-xO precursor in the formation of Co2C nanoprisms with specifically exposed facets was also revealed by Liu et al. [29]. In addition, it was shown that the reduction process could control the morphology of Co2C nanostructures [24], and the morphology of Co2C was found to gradually change from nanoprisms to nanospheres even along with the appearance of metallic cobalt as increasing reaction pressure and CO2 content in the syngas feed [25,30]. It is well-known that the preparation process, especially preparation methods, can dramatically influence the catalytic performance by tuning the physicochemical properties and microstructure of active sites for syngas conversion [31–33]. Han et al. [27] synthesized a series of iron-based catalysts using solid-state reaction, co-precipitation and melting methods, in which the catalyst prepared via simple solid-state reaction method exhibited superior FTO activity and light olefins selectivity (40 %). They proposed the outstanding catalytic performance was attributed to the formation of γ-Fe2O3 precursor phase prepared by solid-state reaction, which facilitated the formation of active phase Fe5C2 with the exposed (021) facet [27]. Mai et al. [28] studied the catalytic performance of FeCuZn catalysts prepared by co-precipitation and impregnation methods for syngas conversion. After carefully comparison, they found that the catalyst obtained by co-precipitated method was easier to be reduced and carburized than the impregnated catalyst, which was benefit for higher CO conversion and C5+ selectivity [27]. Du et al. [34] explored the influence of impregnation strategies of CoFe/AC on the formation of higher alcohols. The 15Co-5Fe/AC catalyst prepared by first impregnating the iron precursor presented the highest CO uptake, metal dispersion and the maximum cobalt surface content, resulting in the enhancement of CO hydrogenation activity as well as the yield of mixed alcohols [34]. In this work, different preparation methods, including precipitation and impregnation were applied to synthesize the CoMn-based catalysts. The catalyst structure and catalytic performance for FTO reaction were investigated in detail. Various characterization techniques such as inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), N2 adsorption and desorption (BET), thermal gravimetric analysis-mass spectrometry (TG-MS), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), in situ or ex situ powder X-ray diffraction patterns (in situ or ex situ XRD), high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) were used to characterize the catalyst samples obtained via different preparation methods. The effect of preparation methods on structure-performance relationship of CoMn catalysts for FTO reaction was also discussed. The results showed that different preparation methods of CoMn-based catalysts had a great influence on the precursor phase of Co species, and finally affected the morphology of Co2C nanostructures as well as the catalytic performance for syngas conversion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Various CoMn catalysts with Co/Mn atomic ratio of 2 were prepared using different preparation methods including precipitation (PR) and impregnation (IM). Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 50 wt% Mn(NO3)2 and Na2CO3 with analytical grade are purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The sample was denoted as PR-CM for the co-precipitation of Co and Mn salt precursors simultaneously, PR-C-M for the fractional precipitation of Co salt firstly, PR-M-C for the fractional precipitation of Mn salt firstly, IM-M/C for Mn salt being impregnated over Co3O4, and IM-C/M for Co salt being impregnated over MnO2. Co3O4 and MnO2 were prepared by their corresponding salts precipitated with Na2CO3. All co-precipitation samples were centrifuged and washed several times with deionized water. PR-CM was synthesized according to the following procedures. Co(NO3)2·6H2O and Mn(NO3)2 were dissolved in deionized water together to form a mixed salt solution. The as-obtained solution and an aqueous solution of sodium carbonate were simultaneously added dropwise to a beaker with 100 mL of deionized water under vigorous stirring at 30 °C. The pH was controlled at about 8.0. After precipitation, the obtained suspension was aged for 2 h at 30 °C and then centrifuged, washed with deionized water before dried at 80 °C for 24 h, and then calcined in a muffle furnace at 350 °C for 4 h under static air. PR-C-M and PR-M-C were prepared using analogous procedures of PR-CM but with a fractional sequence. For PR-C-M, the Co(NO3)2 solution was precipitated firstly and then Mn(NO3)2 solution. While PR-M-C was prepared with a reverse sequence and Mn(NO3)2 solution was precipitated firstly. IM-C/M was prepared by impregnation methods according to the following procedures. MnO2 was firstly synthesized by precipitation method with Na2CO3 solution and calcined in a muffle furnace at 350 °C for 4 h under static air. Then the as-obtained MnO2 support was impregnated with Co(NO3)2 aqueous solution. The sample was dried in air at 120 °C for 24 h, and then calcined in a muffle furnace at 350 °C for 4 h under static air again. IM-M/C were prepared using analogous procedures of IM-C/M but with a reverse sequence. The calcined catalysts were reduced in a tube furnace under flowing atmosphere with 10 vol % of H2/Ar (40 mL/min) as temperature was ramped from 30 °C to 300 °C at a rate of 1 °C/min and then held for 5 h at 300 °C. The reduced catalysts were passivated with 1 vol % O2/Ar for 70 min for structure characterization. 2.2 Characterization ICP-OES (Optima 8000, PerkinElmer) was used to determine the concentration of Co, Mn and Na after sample dissolution according to standard in-house procedures. BET (TriStar II 3020) was used to analyze the surface area and pore structure of all samples by N2 physical adsorption-desorption at −196 °C, using the multipoint BET analysis methods. Prior to the measurements, the calcined and reduced samples were degassed at 120 °C for 12 h while the spent samples were degassed at 180 °C for 12 h. XRD patterns were recorded on an Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation with the wavelength of 1.54056 Å, operated at 40 kV and 40 mA at a scanning rate of 2°/min, with a scanning angle (2θ) ranging from 10-90°. The identification of different phases was performed by comparing the patterns with JCPDS standard files. In situ XRD analysis was performed on a Rigaku Ultima IV equipped with a special in situ heating cell. Sample was placed on a heating stage in the cell, and the cell was sealed with a beryllium window. Then at an air flow of 100 mL/min, the sample were heated from 30 °C to 350 °C and kept 350 °C for 4 h. In situ XRD patterns were scanned from 30–80° at several different temperatures. H2-TPR was performed with a Micromeritics Autochem-II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and an MKS Cirrus 2 mass spectrometer. Typically, 50 mg sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor and pretreated in the He flow of 40 mL/min at 100 °C for 1 h, followed by cooling down to 60 °C. Once the signal was stable, the gas stream was switched to 5 vol % H2/Ar, then the temperature was increased to 800 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min. TG-MS (Netzsch STA 449 Jupyiter) was conducted in flowing air of 50 mL/min and the temperature was increased from 40 °C to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. TEM measurements were performed on a JEOL-JEM 2000FX electron microscope with 200 kV accelerating voltage. Samples for TEM were prepared by dispersing the catalyst samples in ethanol followed by ultrasonication and then dropped on a copper microgrid covered by a holey-carbon film. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation Catalytic performance was carried out in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor. Prior to CO hydrogenation reaction, the 40–60 mesh catalysts were mixed with the same mesh of silica sand as diluent and loaded into a stainless steel reactor. The catalysts were reduced in situ in 10 vol % H2/Ar at atmosphere pressure with a gas flow rate of 40 mL/min at 300 °C for 5 h, and the heating ramp was 1 °C/min. The temperature then decreased to desired temperature in pure He flow for 30 min, to purge the residual reduction gas. Subsequently, H2/CO (v/v) = 1 (H2/CO/N2 = 48.5/48.5/3) was introduced to the reactor as feed gas. The 3 vol % of nitrogen was contained in the feed gas as internal standard. In order to compare the product selectivity at the same level of conversion among different catalysts, CO conversion was adjusted by changing the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) from 500 to 10500 mL/h/gcat at 270 °C. The detailed analysis procedure could be found in our previous literatures [13,35]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure characterization 3.1.1 Composite and textural properties The bulk composition of the calcined catalysts was analyzed by ICP-OES (Table 1 ). The Co/Mn ratio calculated from ICP results was in agreement with the theoretical value. The residual sodium concentrations of all samples were approximately 0.3 wt %, which could promote the Co2C formation [36]. The N2 adsorption-desorption results were shown in Fig. S1. All the samples displayed type V isotherms and had a steep N2 hysteresis, indicating non-uniform mesoporous structure. The pore parameters were listed in Table 1. The samples prepared by precipitation methods showed larger surface areas and pore volumes than the impregnated ones. The BET surface area followed the orders: PR-CM > PR-C-M > PR-M-C > IM-M/C > IM-C/M. After reduction and reaction, the specific surface areas and pore volumes decreased noticeably. 3.1.2 Ex situ & in situ XRD X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was carried out to study the phase composition of various catalysts as shown in Fig. 1 . The XRD results of fresh catalysts (Fig. 1a) suggested that only PR-CM and PR-C-M samples could form CoMn composite carbonate. PR-C-M exhibited the diffraction peaks of Co(CO3)0.5·(OH)·0.11H2O (JCPDS #48-0083), indicating that some of Co species existed independently from Mn. However, PR-M-C catalyst showed the peaks of MnCO3 (JCPDS #44-1472), CoCO3 (JCPDS #11-0692) and Co(CO3)0.5·(OH)·0.11H2O. Thus, it was apparent that different precipitation sequences influenced the final crystal phase by affecting the nucleation and crystal growth processes. Co-precipitation was more beneficial for the combination of Co and Mn than fractional precipitation. And fractional precipitation starting from the Mn salt precursor did not result in CoMn composite carbonate. IM-C/M and IM-M/C samples revealed the peaks of Co3O4 (JCPDS #42-1467) and MnO2 (JCPDS #04-0779) owing to the decomposition of nitrate during drying process, suggesting that impregnation method would lead to the phase separation of Co and Mn. After calcination (Fig. 1b), PR-CM and PR-C-M samples displayed diffraction peaks corresponding to MnCo2O4.5 (JCPDS #32-0297), while MnCO3 and Co3O4 were observed in PR-M-C. IM-C/M and IM-M/C catalysts showed the peaks of Co3O4 and MnO2. The XRD results for the reduced PR-CM (Fig. 1c) exhibited the diffraction peaks corresponding to the CoxMn1-xO phase with a low degree of crystallinity. For PR-C-M sample, fcc-Co (JCPDS #01-1255) could be found except for the CoxMn1-xO phase. In the case of PR-M-C, IM-C/M and IM-M/C, mixtures of CoO (JCPDS #65-2902), MnO (JCPDS #75-0626) and fcc-Co phases were observed. According to previous reports [21,31,37], Mn could hamper the reduction of Co2+ to Co0. Fig. 1c suggested that the reduction extent of Co2+ depended on the interaction degree of Co and Mn. Under the same reduction conditions, CoxMn1-xO could not be completely reduced, while CoO could be reduced to metallic Co phase even in the presence of isolated Mn, and MnO2 could be reduced to MnO. For pure Co3O4 without Mn, it would totally be reduced to metallic Co (Fig. S2). The XRD patterns of spent catalysts were shown in Fig. 1d. For all spent catalysts, Co2C phase (JCPDS #65-1457) with the characteristic peaks at 2θ of 37.0°, 41.2°, 45.6° and 56.7° and MnO phase were clearly observed. For PR-CM and PR-C-M catalysts, CoxMn1-xO phase was still detected at 36.1°, 41.9° and 61.0°, revealing that a part of CoxMn1-xO could be carburized and separated into Co2C and MnO during reaction. For PR-M-C, MnO phase was found, while CoO and MnO were observed in the case of IM-C/M and IM-M/C. To further study the phase evolution of precipitation samples during calcination process, thermal decomposition of different CoMn precursors was carried out under air atmosphere, and in situ XRD patterns were recorded from 80 to 350 °C as shown in Fig. 2 and S3. PR-CM (Fig. 2a) showed that the diffraction peaks attributed to CoMn composite carbonate at 24.7°, 32.0° and 52.9° were weakened gradually as temperature increased and disappeared at 350 °C owing to the full decomposition of carbonate. Meanwhile, the diffraction peaks of MnCo2O4.5 appeared when temperature reached 350 °C. With time-on-stream at 350 °C, the peak intensity of MnCo2O4.5 became stronger. PR-C-M (Fig. S3) showed the same phase transformation. However, for PR-M-C (Fig. 2b), the peaks of MnCO3 at 37.6°, 49.9°, 60.2°, 64.1° disappeared at 350 °C while the peaks at 24.3° for (012) and at 31.4° for (104) still existed although the diffraction intensity decreased, indicating MnCO3 did not completely decompose. In addition, the peaks of CoCO3 at 32.5° and 53.9° disappeared, and the peaks of Co3O4 at 36.9°, 59.1° and 65.1° appeared at 350 °C, indicating that CoCO3 was easier to decompose than MnCO3. 3.1.3 H2-TPR H2-TPR profiles of the calcined catalysts were shown in Fig. 3 . For PR-CM, three peaks were observed. The first peak at 199 °C was ascribed to the partial reduction of CoMn composite oxide, the second peak at 287 °C was assigned to its further reduction, and the third peak originated from its final reduction to Co0 and MnO. PR-C-M sample had a similar reduction process with PR-CM, while all of the peaks shifted to lower temperature. For PR-M-C catalyst, the first peak was attributed to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, and the second peak was ascribed to the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn2+ [21,31]. However, in the case of IM-C/M sample, the reduction peak of Mn4+ to Mn2+ was overlapped with the reduction peak of Co3+ to Co2+ at 230 °C, and the second peak was contributed to the reduction of Co2+ to Co0. IM-M/C sample had similar reduction behavior with that of IM-C/M, but all peaks shifted to higher temperatures. 3.1.4 TG-MS The thermal behavior of precipitated CoMn samples was investigated by TG and DTG as shown in Fig. 4 . The corresponding MS signal during TG process in air was presented in Fig. S4. TG and DTG results of CoCO3 and MnCO3 were also shown in Figs. S5 and S6 for comparison. The weight loss before 180 °C suggested the evaporation of adsorbed water. For PR-CM catalyst, except for the water loss at 153 °C, there was only one obvious weight loss at 309 °C. However, for PR-C-M and PR-M-C samples, there were additional weight loss peaks at 232 °C, 327 °C and 231 °C, 468 °C, respectively. According to the thermal decomposition of CoCO3 and MnCO3 (Fig. S5), the weight loss peak around 226−256 °C was due to the decomposition of CoCO3 and the loss peak at 418−468 °C was attributed to the decomposition of MnCO3. The MS signal (Fig. S4a) of PR-CM indicated that CO2 could be detected only at 309 °C, suggesting the decomposition of CoMn composite carbonate. The weight loss peak around 226−256 °C was due to the decomposition of CoCO3 for PR-C-M and PR-M-C. The loss peak at 418−468 °C was attributed to the decomposition of MnCO3 for PR-M-C, and MnCO3 was more difficult to decompose than CoCO3, in agreement with the XRD results. The loss peak at 309−327 °C was due to the decomposition of CoMn composite carbonate for PR-C-M sample. 3.1.5 (HR)TEM The (HR)TEM images of various spent samples were shown in Fig. 5 . A large number of quadrangular nanoparticles were observed for the PR-CM and PR-C-M catalysts (Fig. 5a, d). According to HRTEM characterization in Fig. 5b and c, the lattice fringe of 2.18 Å was attributed to the Co2C (020) plane in the spent PR-CM, and the quadrangular nanoparticles were in the shape of Co2C nanoprisms with specifically exposed facets of (101) and (020). Similar Co2C nanoprisms were found for PR-C-M (Fig. 5e), but Co2C nanospheres with the lattice fringe of 2.12 Å were also detected (Fig. 5f). However, for PR-M-C (Fig. 5h, i), the lattice fringes of 2.12 Å and 2.19 Å were the characteristic interlayer spacing of Co2C (111) and Co2C (020) planes, respectively. And all the Co2C nanoparticles were spherical morphology. The similar Co2C spherical morphology was observed for IM-C/M (Fig. 5k, l) and IM-M/C (Fig. 5n, o). 3.2 Catalytic performance Table 2 summarized the results of the catalytic performance of different CoMn-based catalysts. CO2 selectivity for all catalysts was above 40 C%, indicating high water-gas shift (WGS) activity. The PR-CM (Entry 1) showed high C2-4 = selectivity (59.4 C%) and low CH4 selectivity (3.9 C%) with high ratio of olefin to paraffin for C2-4 (31.8) at CO conversion of 22.3 C% under 250 °C. For PR-C-M catalyst (Entry 4), the C2-4 = selectivity slightly decreased to 56.5 C% while the CH4 selectivity increased to 4.3 C%, with an obvious lower CO conversion (13.6 C%), and the O/P ratio for C2-4 also decreased to 27.5. When the reaction temperature reached 270 °C, the CO conversion dramatically increased to 38.9 C% for PR-CM (Entry 2) and 23.3 C% for PR-C-M (Entry 5), and the C2-4 = selectivity for those samples was up to 65.5 C%, although the CH4 selectivity increased to 9.1 C% and 10.5 C%, respectively. However, in comparison with PR-CM and PR-C-M samples, PR-M-C, IM-C/M and IM-M/C catalysts (Entry 7, 9 and 11) exhibited a very low activity for FTO reaction even at 270 °C. The PR-M-C by firstly precipitating Mn salt only had 2.2 C% for CO conversion and 40.6 C% for C2-4 = selectivity while the CH4 selectivity dramatically increased to 13.7 C%, suggesting that precipitation sequences possessed a significant influence on the catalytic performance of CoMn catalysts. As for the impregnated catalysts, IM-C/M only displayed 1.7 C% for CO conversion, and the selectivities for C2-4 = and CH4 were 37.6 C% and 17.1 C%, respectively. CO conversion was 4.3 C% while CH4 selectivity was about 15.0 C% for IM-M/C. It was obvious that the catalysts prepared with different preparation methods showed great differences in catalytic behaviors. The product selectivities of all catalysts were also compared at similar CO conversion of ca. 5 C% via changing the space velocity at 270 °C. The results were listed in Table 2 with entry 3, 6, 8, 10, 12. As shown in Fig. 6 , the products selectivities were dramatically different for various catalysts at similar CO conversion. CH4 selectivity was 9.1 C% and 9.9 C% for PR-CM and PR-C-M, respectively. While CH4 selectivity increased to 18.6 C%, 18.5 C% and 22.9 C% for PR-M-C, IM-C/M and IM-M/C samples, respectively. C2-4 = selectivity for PR-CM and PR-C-M reached 68.9 C% and 67.0 C%, respectively. However, PR-M-C, IM-C/M and IM-M/C possessed a poor C2-4 = selectivity with a value lower than 35 C%. We further compared the CO conversion of different CoMn catalysts as a function of time-on-stream as shown in Fig. 7 a. As for PR-CM catalyst, the CO conversion changed considerably over the first 20 h. Once exposed to syngas atmosphere, CO conversion decreased from 18.3 C% to 6.0 C% over the first 5 h, then the catalytic activity increased markedly to 22.3 C% within the next 15 h and seemed to be stable after 20 h. In the case of PR-C-M, similar trend for CO conversion was observed while CO conversion was only 13.6 C% after 20 h. However, the trends of CO conversion for PR-M-C, IM-C/M and IM-M/C samples were different from PR-CM and PR-C-M. For example, at the reaction temperature of 270 °C, PR-M-C showed only 2.2 C% for CO conversion. The trends of product distributions of PR-CM and PR-C-M as a function of time-on-stream were also presented in Fig. S7. In the case of PR-CM (Fig. S7a), CH4 selectivity increased to 3.6 C% and then remained stable after 15 h. The CO2 and C2-4 = selectivities increased dramatically and then kept at 46.3 C% and 59.4 C%, respectively. The selectivity for (C5+ + Oxy.), however, decreased sharply at first, then remained at about 35 C% after 20 h. The evolution of CO conversion and product distribution of PR-CM and PR-C-M were similar to our previous work [13], and the activation process in the initial stages differed from the typical performance of Fischer-Tropsch catalysts. The hydrocarbon distribution at WHSV of 2000 mL/h/gcat was also investigated as shown in Fig. 7b. The chain growth probability (α) was obtained by fitting the results generated for chains of three to seven carbons using the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) model. For PR-CM and PR-C-M at 250 °C, the α value was about 0.42, suggesting similar chain propagation probability. While the α value decreased to nearly 0.36 when the reaction temperature was increased to 270 °C. For PR-M-C, IM-C/M, IM-M/C at 270 °C, the α value was about 0.41. Although Mn as an additive was usually used to suppress the CH4 selectivity [31,38], hydrocarbon distributions were apparently diverse for catalysts prepared with different preparation methods. It was clear that PR-CM and PR-C-M had a great negative deviation from traditional ASF model for CH4, and the extent of deviation for reaction at 250 °C was more negative than that at 270 °C. In contrast, PR-M-C, IM-C/M, and IM-M-C samples obeyed the traditional ASF model. 3.3 Discussion of the effect of preparation methods on catalytic performance Structure characterization showed that different preparation methods dramatically affected the phase composition. For precipitation methods, the precipitation sequences influenced the interaction between Co and Mn species. When Co and Mn salt were simultaneously precipitated, Mn was in close proximity to the Co species to form CoMn composite carbonate. When Co precursor was first precipitated, CoMn composite carbonate was also obtained, although there was still some isolated Co species that did not form composite with Mn. However, when Mn precursor was first precipitated, Mn was completely separated with Co species. For impregnation methods, Co and Mn species could not form CoMn composite oxide because of the phase separation. Therefore, we inferred that the perfect FTO performance of PR-CM and PR-C-M catalysts was owing to the close interaction of Co and Mn to form CoMn composite oxide, and Co2C nanoprisms derived from CoxMn1-xO phase were more active for CO dissociation with higher olefins selectivity than Co2C nanospheres carburized from CoO or fcc-Co. According to our previous works [13,24], Co2C nanostructures had strong facet effects and Co2C nanoprisms with specifically exposed facets of (101) and (020) were beneficial for FTO reaction. The Co2C (101) surface could stabilize the CH2CH2 species, and the Co2C (020) surface was highly active for CO dissociation and also possessed the highest effective barrier for CH4 formation, whereas CO non-dissociative adsorption was preferred on the Co2C (111) surface, which was also highly active for CH4 formation. To obtain the specific Co2C nanoprisms, CoxMn1-xO was the key precursor phase [23], which would be controlled by preparation methods. For PR-CM catalyst, the CoxMn1-xO phase after reduction could gradually evolve into the Co2C nanoprisms during reaction process. In the case of PR-C-M, except for Co2C nanoprisms, spherical Co2C nanoparticles were also obtained because some of Co species could not be combined with Mn to form CoxMn1-xO. However, only spherical Co2C nanoparticles were obtained for PR-M-C, IM-C/M and IM-M/C samples due to the absence of CoxMn1-xO phase. As a result, very poor FTO performance under the identical reaction condition was observed for PR-M-C, IM-C/M and IM-M/C catalysts. 4 Conclusion Fischer-Tropsch to olefins provides a promising route for producing valuable chemicals via syngas conversion. The effect of preparation methods of CoMn-based catalysts on the structure-performance relationship for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins was investigated. The results showed that CoMn spinel oxide was found in the calcined catalysts prepared by co-precipitation of Co and Mn salts or sequential precipitation starting from the Co salt. However, Co3O4 and MnO2 were the major phases for the samples prepared by sequential precipitation starting from the Mn salt or impregnation method (Co supported on MnO2 or Mn supported on Co3O4). During syngas conversion process, those catalysts with CoMn spinel phase could gradually evolve into Co2C nanoprisms with exposed facets of (101) and (020), and exhibited high CO conversion, low methane selectivity and high olefins selectivity. However, Co2C with spherical morphology carburized from fcc-Co or CoO was observed for the other samples, which presented poorer FTO catalytic performance. It was concluded that different preparation methods of CoMn-based catalysts had great influence on the precursor phase of Co species, and finally affected the morphology of Co2C nanostructures as well as the catalytic performance for syngas conversion. coredata.dc:description: The effects of preparation methods for CoMn-based catalysts on the precursor phase of Co species, the morphology of Co2C nanostructures as well as the catalytic performance for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins were investigated. Five catalysts prepared by precipitation and impregnation methods were compared in detail. CoMn spinel oxide was found in the calcined catalysts prepared by co-precipitation or sequential precipitation starting from the Co salt. However, Co3O4 and MnO2 were the major phases for the calcined catalysts prepared by sequential precipitation starting from the Mn salt or impregnation methods. During the syngas conversion process, Co2C nanoprisms with exposed facets of (101) and (020) were generated from CoMn spinel phase, and exhibited high CO conversion, low methane selectivity and high olefins selectivity. In contrast, Co2C nanospheres carburized from metallic Co or CoO were observed for the other samples with poorer FTO catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Fischer-Tropsch to olefins over CoMn-based catalysts: Effect of preparation methods
